content.question:
Half-Reaction
<math alttext="E naught, in volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi><mo>°</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>

<math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus one electron, react to produce A g, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Ag</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="italic">a</mi><mi mathvariant="italic">q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mo>→</mo><mi>Ag</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>
<math alttext="0.80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo> </mo><mn>0.80</mn></math>

<math alttext="N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus two electrons, react to produce N i, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Ni</mi><mpadded><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mpadded></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mo>→</mo><mi>Ni</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>
<math alttext="negative 0.25" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>0.25</mn></mpadded></math>

The standard reduction potentials of the half-reactions associated with a galvanic cell are listed in the table above. Which of the following statements identifies the electrode that increases in mass as the cell operates, and correctly explains why?

choices.label: The <math alttext="A g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ag</mi></math> electrode, because <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Ag</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> in the solution is reduced to form <math alttext="A g, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ag</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.

The <math alttext="A g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ag</mi></math> electrode, because <math alttext="A g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ag</mi></math> has a greater molar mass than <math alttext="N i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ni</mi></math> has.

The <math alttext="N i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ni</mi></math> electrode, because <math alttext="N i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ni</mi></math> is chemically more reactive than <math alttext="A g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ag</mi></math> is.

The <math alttext="N i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ni</mi></math> electrode, because <math alttext="N i with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Ni</mi><mpadded><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mpadded></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is reduced at a faster rate than <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Ag</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is.

content.answer: The <math alttext="A g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ag</mi></math> electrode, because <math alttext="A g with a positive 1 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Ag</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> in the solution is reduced to form <math alttext="A g, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ag</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
